name: Hard Music Lyrics from the 60s and 70s Quiz / Test | Music | 10 Questions

questions.text: 'Long, long time ago, I can still remember how the music used to make me smile.'
questions.explanation:
Don MacLean.

	'American Pie'This was MacLean's only mega-hit, although he also produced other beautiful songs such as "Vincent," about painter Vincent Van Gogh.

questions.text: 'On a morning from a Bogart movie, in a country where they turned back time'
questions.explanation:
Al Stewart.

	'Year of the Cat'Al Stewart has an amazing knack for turning historical events into song. He is probably the only rock figure to write a song about President Warren Harding, for example.

questions.text: 'Sitting on a park bench, eyeing little girls with bad intent. Snot running down his nose, greasy fingers smearing shaggy clothes'
questions.explanation:
Jethro Tull.

	'Aqualung'Jethro Tull's lead singer, Ian Anderson, is also a proficient flautist.

questions.text: 'One pill makes you larger, and one pill makes you small. But the ones that Mother gives you don't do anything at all.'
questions.explanation:
Jefferson Airplane.

	'White Rabbit'Jefferson Airplane epitomizes the Summer of Love, hippies, and acid rock.

questions.text: 'I get by with a little help from my friends'
questions.explanation:
The Beatles.

	'With a Little Help from my Friends'The immortal Beatles are without a doubt one of the most recognized groups worldwide.

questions.text: 'And I dream I'm an eagle. And I dream I can spread my wings.'
questions.explanation:
Abba.

	'Eagle'It is claimed that the Swedish members of Abba had no idea what most of the lyrics that they were singing meant.

questions.text: 'If there's a bustle in your hedgerow, don't be alarmed now'
questions.explanation:
Led Zeppelin.

	"Stairway to Heaven"This song is perennially at the top of almost every "Top Whatever Rock Songs" list.

questions.text:
Out in the woods
 Or in the city
 It's all the same to me
 When I'm drivin' free, the world's my home
 When I'm mobile
questions.explanation:
The Who.

	'Goin Mobile'The Who often presented a tough, workingman's front, but they had some light and hopeful songs such as this one as well.

questions.text:
'Well, there's a rose in the fisted glove 
And the eagle flies with the dove'
questions.explanation:
Stephen Stills.

	'Love the One You're With'This was probably Stills' most successful song after he broke up with CSN&Y.

questions.text: 'On the bloody morning after, one tin soldier rides away'
questions.explanation:
Coven.

	'One Tin Soldier'- their only hit!
